item.title: A mental math heuristic to convert between Fahrenheit and Celsius | Evan Hahn (dot com)
item.description: I sometimes have to convert between Fahrenheit and Celsius. The actual formula is hard to do in my head, but someone once told me a useful approximation:To convert from Celsius to Fahrenheit, double i
item.content:encoded: I sometimes have to convert between Fahrenheit and Celsius. The actual formula is hard to do in my head, but someone once told me a useful approximation:To convert from Celsius to Fahrenheit, double it and add 30.To convert from Fahrenheit to Celsius, subtract 30 and halve it (the reverse).For example, if it’s 12ºC, this heuristic would return 54ºF. (12 × 2) + 30 = 54. The actual amount is not far off: 53.6ºF.To convert the other way: 68ºF becomes 19ºC. (68 − 30) ÷ 2 = 19. Again, this is close t

item.title: Five things successful IT teams get right about SaaS management | Blog on 1Password Blog
item.description: It’s easy to see how SaaS sprawl happens if you picture the moment it starts. A team is blocked, someone needs a tool ASAP, and the answer to their problems lies just behind a free trial, so they sign
item.content:encoded: It’s easy to see how SaaS sprawl happens if you picture the moment it starts. A team is blocked, someone needs a tool ASAP, and the answer to their problems lies just behind a free trial, so they sign up for a new tool. No one is being careless. They’re being efficient. The problem is that follow-up rarely keeps pace with new sign-ups, especially when the card on file belongs to "the company" and the requester has already moved on to the next priority.Months later, you realize you are paying for

item.content:encoded: I set all of Vim’s configuration options. I still feel far from mastery.First impressions of Vim: wowI first saw someone use Vim during an internship in 2012.I had been coding for many years and I fancied myself pretty good at shortcuts, but I was quickly humbled. item.content:encoded: Unused SaaS licenses are a budget drain and a security risk. The need to easily track and manage SaaS licenses and identify unused ones is a challenge that every modern organization faces. The problem is that most IT teams can’t confidently answer a basic question: Are we using the licenses that we’re paying for? Why? item.content:encoded: From Chrome 145 onwards, 100vw will automatically subtract the size of the (vertical) scrollbar from it if you have forced the html element to always show a vertical scrollbar (using overflow[-y]: scroll) or if you reserve space for it (using scrollbar-gutter: stable). The same applies to vh with a horizontal scrollbar, as well as all small, large, and dynamic variants.

item.description: Models are powerful, but they're limited to their training data and knowledge cutoff date. When users ask about today's news, current prices, or the latest API changes, models can offer outdated infor
item.content:encoded: Models are powerful, but they're limited to their training data and knowledge cutoff date. When users ask about today's news, current prices, or the latest API changes, models can offer outdated information or admit they don't know.Provider-agnostic web search on AI Gateway changes this. With a single line of code, you can give any model the ability to search the web in real-time. It works with OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, and every other provider available through AI Gateway.Read more

item.content:encoded: We shipped build system optimizations that reduce overhead for projects with many input files, large , or large build outputs.node_modulesExpensive disk operations (large file detection and folder size calculations) are no longer on the critical path for successful builds. item.content:encoded: Rails 8.1.0 introduces the except_on option for validations and validation callbacks, making it easier to skip them in specific contexts.In Rails, we can conditionally run validations.
